title: Upgrades will finally fix Wi-Fi at Ford Field
text:
Upgrades will finally fix Wi-Fi at Ford Field The Lions showed off upgraded cellular and Wi-Fi technology that the franchise expects to improve game-day experience. The Detroit Lions showed off its upgraded cellular and Wi-Fi service today at Ford Field, highlighting a technology that required installing new copper and fiber optic cable throughout the stadium and that the franchise hopes will fix connectivity problems and improve the experience at games, concerts and other events. 
"We recognize that access to technology and social media plays an integral role in the fan experience at NFL games," said Rod Wood, the team president. "It is imperative the we provide optimal connectivity for everybody at Ford Field." 
The Lions, who have been vowing for months to fix problems, have faced complaints from frustrated fans who said they could not connect to the Internet — and wireless phone service — to access apps and social media, replay clips, see fantasy football updates and even send text messages and make phone calls during games. 
►Related: Ford Field Wi-Fi will be available to all Lions fans, Verizon says 
To address the problem, Verizon — the wireless carrier that put in the system in 2012 — said it has quadrupled capacity in the 65,000-seat stadium. It drilled into the concrete walls, pulled cables throughout the stadium, and added antenna systems, some of which are mounted to the silver handrails in the aisles. 
The wires are hidden inside the handrails and run underneath the stadium. Buy Photo 
New equipment embedded in handrails at Ford Field helps improves the stadium's wireless connectivity. (Photo: Frank Witsil, Detroit Free Press) 
Users, however, won't be able to connect to Wi-Fi if they are using the hot spot feature on their phone. 
This year's improvements — some of which are ready now and some that are still being worked on — are expected to allow all guests with any wireless carrier to log on to wireless Internet at no charge by the start of football season, the team said. The upgrades also are expected to provide more tech opportunities for guests, including augmented and virtual reality. 
Lions officials said it's too early to talk about what those new tech features or devices would be like, and how fans would use them while watching the game, but they are likely in the future — and the more reliable, higher speed connections likely would be essential in order for them to operate. 
Until the improvements, access had been limited to Verizon customers because — as the company said when it installed it — it was seeking investment from other phone carriers to help cover the initial $4-million cost to build the network. 
Verizon and the Lions said the upgrades cost millions of dollars, but declined to be more specific. 
The Lions said that the upgrade cost would not be passed along through increased ticked prices. 
Ford Field was the first major stadium in Michigan, and the ninth in the NFL, to offer fans wireless Internet service. 
In 2012, NFL commissioner Roger Goodell said the league wanted Wi-Fi in all the stadiums so that fans could have access to the same information they would at home, including highlights, social media and fantasy football. 
The next year, the Lions started hyping its Wi-Fi services, which the team said it needed to help compete with the home viewing experience. 
But, one of the problems with wireless phone connectivity in stadiums, and places where many people are gathered, is that it doesn't work well when many people are trying to use it all at once. 
It's almost like a traffic jam, and installing systems that worked was more complicated than the carrier initially thought. 
In addition to improving Wi-Fi, Verizon also is installing new equipment to handle and enhance cellular service through the stadium. For Verizon customers, especially those on unlimited data plans, the upgrades give fans two ways — Wi-Fi or through the carrier's network — to send and receive information,engineer Doug Kwiatkowski said
